Banerjee spent three years at Presidency, receiving a BSc (Honors) in Economics in 1981.
He completed his degree in 1983, and was encouraged by his parents and teachers to apply for PhD programs in economics.
He was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2004.
In 2009, he received the Infosys Prize in the social sciences (economics) category.
In 2012, he shared the Gerald Loeb Award Honorable Mention for Business Book with co-author Esther Duflo for their book Poor Economics.
In 2013, he was named by the United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to a panel of experts tasked with updating the Millennium Development Goals after 2015 (their expiration date).
In 2014, he received the Bernhard-Harms-Prize from the Kiel Institute for the World Economy.
He served on the Social Sciences jury for the Infosys Prize in 2018.
In 2019, he delivered Export-Import Bank of India's 34th Commencement Day Annual Lecture on Redesigning Social
That same year, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics, together with Esther Duflo and Michael Kremer,
In October 2025, the University of Zurich announced that Banerjee and Duflo would be joining the faculty of the UZH Faculty of Business, Economics, and Informatics in July 2026,
In October 2025, the University of Zurich announced that Banerjee and Duflo would be joining the faculty of the UZH Faculty of Business, Economics, and Informatics in July 2026,
In India he serves on the academic advisory board of Plaksha University, a science and technology university established in 2010.
Banerjee wrote a cookbook in 2021, Cooking To Save Your Life, published by Juggernaut.
Abhijit and Arundhati had one son together and later divorced. Their son, born in 1991, died in an accident in 2016.
Their son, born in 1991, died in an accident in 2016.
In 2015, Banerjee married his co-researcher, MIT professor Esther Duflo;
In 2015, Banerjee married his co-researcher, MIT professor Esther Duflo; they have two children, Noemie Banerjee (born 2012) and Milan Banerjee (born 2014).

Nobel laureates in Economics
Born February 21, 1961, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India
Banerjee was born to a Bengali father and a Marathi mother in Mumbai
Banerjee attended secondary school at South Point School in Kolkata
His father, Dipak Banerjee, was a professor of economics at Presidency College, Calcutta

The Nobel Prize was a major recognition for their chosen field - Development Economics, and for the use of Randomised Controlled Trials. It evoked mixed emotions in India, where his success was celebrated with nationalistic fervour while his approach and pro-poor focus were seen as a negation of India's current government's right-wing ideology as well as broader development discourse.

BJP leader Rahul Sinha, who had served as the state BJP president in Banerjee's native state of West Bengal, downplayed his achievements and alleged Anti-Indian sentiment on the part of the Nobel Committee.
He was born in Mumbai in 1961; his mother, who is also an economist, is a Marathi.

Banerjee was born to a Bengali father and a Marathi mother in Mumbai
Banerjee attended secondary school at South Point School in Kolkata
His father, Dipak Banerjee, was a professor of economics at Presidency College, Calcutta
His mother, Nirmala (née Patankar) Banerjee was a professor at the Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta
After completing his undergraduate studies, Banerjee pursued an MA in Economics at Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi
the latter's reputation as a stepping stone to PhD programs in the United States
He completed his degree in 1983, and was encouraged by his parents and teachers to apply for PhD programs in economics.
He was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2004.
In 2009, he received the Infosys Prize in the social sciences (economics) category.
In 2012, he shared the Gerald Loeb Award Honorable Mention for Business Book with co-author Esther Duflo for their book Poor Economics.
In 2013, he was named by the United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to a panel of experts tasked with updating the Millennium Development Goals after 2015 (their expiration date).
In 2014, he received the Bernhard-Harms-Prize from the Kiel Institute for the World Economy.
He served on the Social Sciences jury for the Infosys Prize in 2018.
In 2019, he delivered Export-Import Bank of India's 34th Commencement Day Annual Lecture on Redesigning Social
